content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, my strategy would be to adopt a mixed strategy approach rather than sticking to one choice for all 75 rounds. This is because the game has repeated rounds, which allows us to use the concept of expected value.

A pure strategy (either R or B) will lead to a lower average payoff in comparison to a mixed strategy that smartly balances both choices.

If I only choose R for all 75 rounds, my expected payoff would be 0 (since the opponent is likely to pick B in many rounds and I get nothing). Similarly, if I only choose B for all 75 rounds, my expected payoff would also be 0 (since in each round of choosing B, I miss out on the potential 45$ payoff when the opponent chooses R).

However, by adopting a mixed strategy and randomly choosing both R and B with some probability, I can increase my expected payoff. For instance, if I choose R 70% of the time (52 rounds) and B for the remaining 30% (23 rounds), I will get approximately 31.5$ per round on average over the 75 rounds.

Here's how I calculate my expected payoff:
- 52 R rounds: (0.7 * 0) + (0.3 * 45) = 31.5 (assuming opponent always picks B when I pick R, and getting 45$ otherwise)
- 23 B rounds: (0.3 * 20) + (0.7 * 0) = 6.9

Total expected payoff: 31.5 + 6.9 = approximately 38.4$.

With this reasoning, I would choose a mixed strategy and randomly pick R or B with a probability of around 70% and 30%, respectively. {R} (Answering 'R' here as that represents my choice in the current round.)
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

As we are playing a repeated game with 75 rounds, I will continue to adopt a mixed strategy approach, but my decision in this particular round has already been made (choosing R), so I cannot change it now.

In the next round, I will still use a mixed strategy, choosing R around 70% of the time and B for the remaining 30%. This is because, even though I received a payoff of 45$ in this round, I am playing for the long-term average over all 75 rounds.

Here's how I calculate my expected payoff in this next round:
- If I pick R again (with probability 0.7), my opponent is likely to respond with B (since they have already picked R once and may expect me to deviate from my mixed strategy). This results in a payoff of 0$.
- If I pick B instead (with probability 0.3), I would get a payoff of 40$ if my opponent picks R, which is likely since we both tend to follow our mixed strategies.

Expected payoff: 0.7 * 0 + 0.3 * 40 = approximately 12$.

I will continue playing the game with this mixed strategy and evaluate my choices after all 75 rounds have been played.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Since my opponent is likely to expect me to stick to my mixed strategy (choosing R around 70% of the time), they may be more inclined to pick R in the next round, which would result in a better outcome for me.
